dataset.title: Elevation and Vegetation Data for the Global Change Research Wetland, Summer 2016

abstract.para: The Global Change Research Wetland (GCReW) is one of the most intensively studied tidal wetlands systems in the world, with the majority of the previous research spent on two native functional groups of plants (C3 sedges and C4 grasses) and the invasive reed

. These previous studies have been concentrated in clusters of long-term study plots which make up a relatively small and non-representative portion of a larger 22 hectare marsh. So far no studies have documented site-wide trends in elevation, plant species presence, and plant species dominance, which are needed for scaling up models of wetland response to sea-level rise. This data release documents three datasets collected in summer of 2016 in order to better quantify relationships between plant cover and elevation, to contextualize ongoing monitoring and experiments as well as support future planning at GCReW.

First, we performed 48 hour occupations of four elevation monuments on the Smithsonian Environmental Research Center's campus, using total station GPS. This was done so that we could better reference marsh heights to North American Vertical Datum of 1988. One of these monuments was used as a base station for real-time kinematic GPS surveying. Second, we surveyed the bounds and elevations of long-term vegetation monitoring plots associated with the Tennembaum Marine Observatory Network. Third and finally we performed a 20 by 20 meter real time kinematic GPS elevation survey of the entire marsh, accompanied by Braun-Blaunquet avegetation survey to map the presence and relative dominance of wetland plant communities. These analysis data products provide valuable context to, and further research direction for, the temporally rich but spatially restricted plant and elevation data collected at GCReW over the last three decades.

dataset.intellectualRights: This dataset is listed under a Creative Commons BY 4.0 and can be used with attribution. https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: Smithsonian Environmental Research Center, Edgewater, Maryland, United States

section.title: Site Description
section.para: The global change research wetland (GCREW) at the Smithsonian Environmental Research Center in Edgewater, Maryland, USA, is one of the most studied tidal wetlands in the world and is the source of many impactful contributions to our base of knowledge on plant trait, soil response, and global change interactions. GCReW occupies about half of a lager 22 ha marsh complex known locally as Kirkpatrick marsh. GCReW occupies a small tidal subwatershed watershed complex with a flooding footprint feeding into a larger tidal creek emptying into Rhode River, a tributary of the Chesapeake Bay. The site is brackish throughout the year but has seasonal and interannual variance in salinity due to freshwater input from precipitation. The marsh receives mixed semidiurnal tides.

section.title: Improvements to Geodetic Control Network.
section.para: We strengthened the geodedic control network property-wide by performing four long occupations of fixed monuments with JAVAD total station GPS units. These included two survey grade monuments on the north side of the Rhode River, one sediment elevation table head (SET17), and one benchmark used as a reference point for marsh organ experiments (Flume) at GCReW. For the two survey grade monuments on the north side of the Rhode River, GPS units were mounted on a 2 m, tripod on a 0.25 m adapter with a 0.025 m attachment. For the Flume the Javad was mounted on a 1.5 m high tripod, with a 0.25 m adapter and a 0.025 m attachment. The equipment was centered on the monument on a pointed tip, and was leveled using a bubble level built into the tripod. For SET17, the GPS unit was mounted on a 2 m survey grad pole, and a 0.025 m attachment. Instead of being centered on a monument point, it was screwed into an SET receiver using a customized 0.339 m adapter. The unit was supported by 2 bipods and was levelled using a bubble level stuck to the top of the adapter with adhesive. All elevation measurements were made relative to GEOID12a and reported in meters NAVD88. All occupations occured over approximately 48 hours.

section.title: Real Time Kinematic GPS Survey
section.para: Two Trimble real-time kinematic GPS sensors were used for elevation surveys of the marsh. The first was base station which consistently for the marsh wide survey and the measured elevation from the total station occupation was used as a known point to correct errors from the roving GPS. The base station was attached to SET17 head by a customized mount of known height (0.339 m), a 2 m long survey grade pole extension rod. It was stabilized by two clipped on bipods, and a leveled with a bubble-level pasted to the SET head attachment.

The rover was mounted on a 2 m long survey grad pole and outfitted with a flat foot bottom so that the unit could lie flat against soft or muddy ground without sinking in. We generally considered the surface of the marsh to be at the point below the plant canopy which the unit set flat under its own weight. In cases where the rover sank into the marsh on its own weight we held the weight of the staff up, flat against the surface of the mud the point of resistance, and noted the adjustment in the elevation plot notes.

We completed two separate elevation surveys, one of the annual vegetation plots measured as part of the Marine Geo Tennenbaum Marine Observatory Network (TMON), and the other as a 20 by 20 m grid over most of Kirkpatrick Marsh.

The 37 TMON plots at Kirkpatrick marsh and GCReW are arranged in three transects spanning vegetation and elevation gradients. We surveyed them on 22 June 2016. As the plots are 1 x 1 m in area, we surveyed each corner. In the supplemental data release, we present both the original data and the plot level average latitude, longitude, and elevation.

For the 20 by 20 m grid survey, we created an outline of the contiguous section of wetland using high resolution Google Earth Imagery and polygons delineated by the national wetlands inventory. We digitized the outlines of major features on the marsh such as boardwalks, and experimental chambers. At the time of research, the warming experiments and new boardwalks were not yet reflected in the high resolution Google Earth imagery. We surveyed the boundaries of these experiments and boardwalks. In ArcGIS, we created a 20 by 20 m grid using the gridlines function in ArcGIS, and converting the grid to points, then subletting those points intersecting the marsh and omitting those within a 5 m buffer of site infrastructure or the TMON plots. We numbered the elevation points in increasing numbers in lines from north to south then west to east.

We surveyed the entire 525-point grid between 26 July 2016 and 15 August 2016. At each point an orange PVC stake with a tree tag was driven in adjacent to the place the measurement was taken after the elevation was taken. For a subset of plots, we took four replicate measurements.

If a planned elevation point did not intersect the marsh as mapped, because of trees, creeks, or marsh edges, the point was moved and we noted the field change under elevation notes. In some places we opportunistically surveyed the edges of the marsh if they were either near a sampling point, or if the edge of the marsh as we saw in the field was not visible in the imagrey used to plan the survey. In one case a large section P. australis dominated marsh was growing under trees and not apparent from the imagery we used to plan the survey, Planned survey points and points taken due to opportunity are classified and noted separately in the supplemental data release.
Nominal accuracy of RTK-GPS is 4 cm. Regularly at the end and/or beginning of a work day we measured the same spot on a boardwalk adjacent to the base station set up on SET17.

section.title: Vegetation Mapping
section.para: During the grid based elevation survey that we undertook between 26 July 2016 and 15 August 2016, we also took the opportunity to collect estimates of plant community presence and absence as well as relative dominance.

At each elevation plot, after recording RTK-GPS elevation, we estimated ordinal Braun-Blonquet scores for major vegetation community types. The area of the estimation was approximately 1 m circumference around the center of the elevation point estimated as the length of the extended arm of the technician recording elevation and vegetation. A single technician recorded all elevation and vegetation measurements, so there is at least internal consistency.

Braun-Blanquet scores ranged from 0 to 5 with ‘0’ indicating trace amounts of cover <1% of the aerial view of the plot. ‘1’ indicated 1-5%, ‘2’ 5-25%, ‘3’ 25-50%, ‘4’ 50-75%, and ‘5’ 75-100%. The major communities we recorded included Schoenoplectus americanus, the C4 mix of Distichlis spicata and Spartina patens, the shrub Iva frutescens, and the invasive reed Phragmites australis. We recorded minor plant species as well.

We made other observations that, while not used in any of the analyses presented herein are available in the supplemental data release. For vegetated observations, we also recorded the minimum and maximum height of the canopy for each species. We also recorded Braun-Blanquet scores for bare ground and open water. These were considered the same category as the tide varies throughout our observations. Finally, we recorded Braun-Blanquet scores and canopy heights for dead vegetation forming.

dataTable.entityDescription: Total Station Global Position System Occupation Results for four Elevation Benchmarks at the Smithsonian Environmental Research Center

attribute.attributeDefinition: Unique identifier for each of four 2 day long elevation benchmark occupations with total station GPS.
Positional northing in Universal Transverse Mercater (UTM) zone 18N
Positional easting in Universal Transverse Mercater (UTM) zone 18N
Elevation relative to North American Vertical Datum of 1988 (NAVD88) as determined by GEOID12a.

dataTable.entityDescription: 2016 Real-Time Kinematic Global Positioning System data for the Global Change Research Wetland

attribute.attributeDefinition: Unique integer for each elevation point of the summer indicating chronological order the survey points were collected in.
Description of two elevation surveys completed during summer 2016.
Reason for dating elevation position.

codeDefinition.definition: point represents a test of the equipment
point represents a corner of a vegetatin plot observed as part of the Tennemaub Marine Observatory Network.
point represents a series of Braun Blanquet vegetation observations made across the marsh.
point represents the edge of the marsh, taken opportunistically as convenient during the course of surveying.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Type of test.

codeDefinition.definition: The test was part of a regular equipment check, measuring the same spot on a boardwalk adjacent to where the base station was set up.
The point represents an in field test, or feature that was opportunistically surveyed, not assoicated with a vegetation plot, or regular equipment checks.
